channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Young Women Take a Frontline Role in Thailand’s Protests
item.description: Women, many of them students, are speaking out against a patriarchy that controls the military, the monarchy and the Buddhist monkhood, Thailand’s most powerful institutions.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Amanda Mustard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sirin Mungcharoen said she was mocked by male activists for promoting feminism and L.G.B.T.Q. rights as integral to democracy.

item.title: With Coronavirus on the Rampage, Israel Tightens Holiday Lockdown
item.description: The new measures go into effect on Friday and will remain in place until at least mid-October.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: A square in Tel Aviv on Sunday. Most businesses and workplaces will have to close under the new rules, and all gatherings, including protests and communal prayers, will be restricted.

item.title: France Doubles Paid Paternity Leave to 28 Days, One of Europe’s Most Generous Plans
item.description: “When a baby arrives in the world, there is no reason it should be just the mother who takes care of it,” President Emmanuel Macron said in announcing the extension.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Researchers in Europe have long documented the benefits of paternity leaves on fathers, their partners and their children.

item.title: North Korea Accused of Shooting and Burning South Korean Defector
item.description: The body of the fisheries official was set ablaze in the North’s waters for fear he was carrying the coronavirus, South Korean officials said.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: The North Korean coastline in the distance as viewed from the South Korean island of Yeonpyeong in 2018. When North Korea finds defectors from ​the ​South, it usually detains them alive.

item.title: China Is Expanding Detention Sites in Muslim Region of Xinjiang
item.description: China said it was winding down its “re-education” camps for Uighurs and other minorities, but researchers found evidence that incarceration is on the rise.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Austin Ramzy
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Joshua Wong Is Arrested in Hong Kong
item.description: Joshua Wong, one of Hong Kong’s most visible pro-democracy activists, suggested that the authorities had political motives for charging him, at a time when the coronavirus has made mask-wearing ubiquitous.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Yu
item.media:description: Joshua Wong, left, the Hong Kong pro-democracy activist, said on Thursday that he would “still continue to resist.”

item.title: A Manila Barbershop’s Mirrors Reflect the Pain of the Pandemic
item.description: Seven months since the Philippines enacted its first lockdown, Jolog’s Barbershop exemplifies the toll the coronavirus has exacted on the country in lost lives, income and sense of community.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez and Jes Aznar
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jolog’s barber Rollie Magalona cutting the hair of a customer inside their shop on September 5, 2020 in Mandaluyong city. Jes Aznar for The New York TimesJes Aznar for The New York Times

item.title: Covid-19 Live News
item.description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said his state would conduct its own review of vaccines authorized by the federal government amid concern that the approval process has become politicized.

item.title: As Coronavirus Cases Surge in Europe, Hospitalizations Lag
item.description: For now, countries are betting they can suppress hospital admissions and deaths without imposing more lockdowns, even as case numbers approach peak levels from last spring.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Medical residents protesting their working conditions on Tuesday in Barcelona, Spain.

item.title: Saudi King, in First U.N. Speech, Assails Longtime Nemesis Iran
item.description: King Salman of Saudi Arabia used his speech to brand Iran as a force for chaos in the Middle East, but he addressed none of his country’s own controversies.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: Eskinder Debebe/UN Photo, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A message pre-recorded by King Salman of Saudi Arabia was played during the General Assembly on Wednesday.

item.title: Aleksandr Lukashenko Sworn In as Belarus President in Secret Ceremony
item.description: Despite weeks of mass demonstrations against his re-election, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko declared victory over protesters as he began a sixth term.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Belta, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus took the oath of office in Minsk on Wednesday.

item.title: Basketball Persists in Mexico Amid the Pandemic
item.description: The Astros de Jalisco are competing in Mexico’s top professional basketball league during the pandemic. But several teams have decided it’s not worth playing.
item.dc:creator: Nathaniel Janowitz

item.title: Argentina Spied on Families of Lost Submarine Crew, Officials Say
item.description: The families had grown angry at the former government for delaying the search operation and giving them what turned out to be false hope. Now, the new government says spies tracked the families.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi
item.media:credit: Erica Canepa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives of the crew members of the San Juan submarine have been demanding answers from the Argentine government since the vessel sank in 2017, killing 44 people on board.

item.title: Russia Freezes Navalny’s Assets as He Recovers From Poisoning
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny was still in a medically induced coma in Berlin when a court in Russia froze his bank accounts and barred him from selling or mortgaging his apartment in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny at Charité hospital in Berlin, in an undated photo taken from a video posted by Mr. Navalny on his Instagram account.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Xinjiang detentions, Europe second wave, North Korea: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: E.U. Failure to Impose Sanctions on Belarus Lays Bare Its Weakness
item.description: E.U. foreign policy moves require unanimous support from the member nations — a rule that continually undercuts the bloc’s bold ambitions for global influence.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Vadim Zamirovski/Tut.by, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An opposition rally in Minsk this month.

item.title: BAFTA Takes Steps on Diversity, After All-White, All-Male Shortlists
item.description: Voters in Britain’s version of the Oscars will have to take unconscious bias training, and there will be a quota for women in the first round of voting for best director.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:credit: Yui Mok/PA Wire, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A BAFTAs trophy. On Thursday, the organization that presents the awards announced new measures to encourage more diversity among nominees.

item.title: Donald Kendall, Pepsi’s Chief During the Cola Wars, Dies at 99
item.description: He faced off against Coke, wooed a ‘Pepsi generation’ and bought Frito-Lay, fast food chains and 7Up. Ever loyal, he downed a Pepsi for breakfast.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: Donald M. Kendall, the chief executive of PepsiCo, in 1969. He worked for the company for 44 years and was called its “architect.”

item.title: Emails Show How Pesticide Industry Influenced U.S. Position in Health Talks
item.description: The U.S. insisted that new international guidelines on combating drug resistance omit any mention of fungicides — a demand that the industry made but that ran counter to science.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The emails were written in 2018 and offer a peek at how the powerful pesticide industry influences U.S.D.A. policy decisions that can affect billions of people across the globe.

item.title: Losing Your Hair Can Be Another Consequence of the Pandemic
item.description: Doctors are seeing a huge increase in patients who have been shedding abnormal amounts of hair, and they believe it is related to stress associated with the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Eve Edelheit for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mrs. Rowe doffed a blond wig in her home.

item.title: 40 days to Nov. 3
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Robert Cohen/St. Louis Post-Dispatch, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Voters waited to cast their ballots early in St. Ann, Mo., on Tuesday.

item.title: The Future of Airbnb
item.description: Home-sharing’s challenges aren’t only about social distancing and hygiene. Overtourism, racial bias, fee transparency and controlling the party crowd are also in the mix.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: Even as Coronavirus Surges, Hungary Plans Super Cup Soccer Game
item.description: Bayern Munich and Sevilla battled for the European trophy in Budapest despite growing concerns over fan safety.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Novak
item.media:description: Sevilla supporters at the UEFA Super Cup soccer match between Bayern Munich and Sevilla in Budapest, on Thursday.

item.title: Breonna Taylor, Coronavirus Vaccine, Belarus: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Cheryl Gerber/Johnson & Johnson, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Johnson & Johnson will recruit participants for its vaccine trial in the U.S., Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Peru and South Africa.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: A massive market in Mexico City is emblematic of the region’s struggles.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: E.U. Offers Cash and More Deportations in New Plan for Migrants
item.description: The bloc wants to persuade its most anti-immigrant member countries to agree to a common policy. But the future of its new plan, like many of its details, remains uncertain.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees from Afghanistan who were displaced from Moria camp after a fire destroyed much of the camp in Lesbos earlier this month.

item.title: U.S. Rationale for Military Aid to Saudis in Yemen War Is Fraying
item.description: The Trump administration argues that its partnership with Saudi Arabia helps reduce civilian killings in Yemen. But State Department investigators and other U.S. officials say the efforts are flawed.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A building that was destroyed by a Saudi-led airstrike in Sanaa, Yemen, in April. The bombing campaign has killed thousands of civilians.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Vaccine, United Nations, virus-sniffing dogs: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Cheryl Gerber/Johnson & Johnson, via Associated Press

item.title: Helsinki Airport Uses Dogs to Sniff Out Coronavirus
item.description: Several animals now working on a trial at Helsinki’s airport have been trained to detect the virus by scent on arriving passengers.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: One of the dogs trained to detect the coronavirus with its trainer at the Helsinki airport.

item.title: Harry and Meghan Encourage Americans to Vote in November Election
item.description: The couple did not endorse any candidates, but Meghan called the election “the most important election of our lifetime.”
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: The couple in London earlier this year. Meghan, a U.S. citizen, has said she plans to vote in November’s presidential election.

item.title: U.S. Ambassador to Netherlands Questioned About Political Interference
item.description: The outspoken conservative envoy, Pete Hoekstra, has been criticized for hosting a fund-raiser for a Dutch populist party at the U.S. Embassy.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Ambassador Pete Hoekstra in Opijnen, the Netherlands, in May.

item.title: Eiffel Tower Briefly Evacuated After Bomb Threat
item.description: The Paris police cordoned off the area around the monument after receiving an anonymous phone call, but the site reopened two hours later.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: French police stand guard near the Eiffel Tower on Wednesday.

item.title: Trudeau Promises Bold Plan for Canada in Throne Speech
item.description: The prime minister promised dramatic actions to fix the economy and more as Parliament resumes. But his agenda is short on detail.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada listening to the national anthem before his legislative agenda was presented to Parliament in Ottawa on Wednesday.

item.title: China’s Pledge to Be Carbon Neutral by 2060: What It Means
item.description: Under international pressure to do more to address global warming, Xi Jinping made a surprise commitment to drastically reduce emissions. Now comes the hard part.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: A coal processing plant in Hejin, China, in November.

item.title: How Trump Can Win
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: President Trump supporters a campaign event for Joe Biden in Lancaster, Pa. in June.

item.title: Undercutting Scientists, Trump Says Tightening Covid-19 Vaccine Guidelines ‘Sounds Like a Political Move’
item.description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci and three other top U.S. health officials told lawmakers they would take a vaccine approved by the F.D.A. Johnson & Johnson announced plans to enroll 60,000 people in a major vaccine trial. Israel will tighten its coronavirus restrictions on Friday.

item.title: In the Epicenter of Mexico's Coronavirus Epicenter, Feeling Like a 'Trapped Animal'
item.description: For the vast majority of people in one teeming neighborhood of Mexico City, risking illness or death has simply become the price of survival.
item.dc:creator: Azam Ahmed and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The burial of a coronavirus victim in the cemetery in the Iztapalapa neighborhood of Mexico City.

item.title: Pakistan Factory Fire: Two Sentenced to Hang for Arson
item.description: The country’s worst industrial fire killed more than 260 people in 2012. Victims’ relatives said the real culprits had escaped justice.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Salman Masood
item.media:description: A police officer stood guard in 2012 at the scene of the fire in Karachi, Pakistan, that killed hundreds of workers.

item.title: Russian Opposition Leader Navalny Leaves Hospital After Poisoning
item.description: Doctors treating Aleksei Navalny said he had been discharged after 32 days of treatment and could make a full recovery.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: A picture posted on social media on Sept. 23 showing Mr. Navalny in Berlin. He was poisoned with a highly toxic nerve agent last month.

item.title: Boris Johnson, United Nations, Climate Change: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Former Rebel Leader Is Elected President of Bougainville
item.description: Ishmael Toroama is expected to lead talks in the South Pacific autonomous region’s effort to seek independence from Papua New Guinea.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: Voting during a non-binding independence referendum in Arawa, on the island of Bougainville in November.

item.title: Ricin Suspect Threatened to Kill Trump Over Re-election Campaign, Prosecutors Say
item.description: The woman was found with a loaded gun and knife when she was arrested on Sunday while trying to enter the United States from Canada.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:description: A woman suspected of trying to mail the lethal substance ricin to President Trump appeared at the federal courthouse in Buffalo on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Demands U.N. Hold China to Account for Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: In speeches broadcast at this year’s Covid-compromised General Assembly, the presidents of China and the United States punctuated an intensifying schism between the two superpowers.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: A message pre-recorded by President Trump was played during the General Assembly on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg puts the the Affordable Care Act in peril.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Dani Blum

item.title: Moussa Traore, Longtime President of Mali, Is Dead at 83
item.description: He seized power in a military coup in 1968 and ruled for 22 years, before being overthrown in another coup.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Moussa Traore in 1984. He was ousted in a coup in 1991.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: U.S.-China tensions, the United Nations, whales in Tasmania: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Alberto Alcain/Malacanang Presidential Photographers Division, via Associated Press

item.title: TikTok and WeChat: What They Tell Us About the Global Internet
item.description: Banned apps, nefarious theories, trade wars, voiceless users. The case of TikTok isn’t news to most of the world.
item.dc:creator: John Herrman

item.title: Facebook Takes Down Fake Pages Created in China Aimed at Trump, Biden
item.description: The social media campaign was small but targeted all sides of the debate. Officials said Beijing had not decided whether to wade more directly in the American presidential race.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman, Sheera Frenkel and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Facebook identified a range of fake accounts pushing information about American and Philippine politics and Chinese activity in the South China Sea.

item.title: British Give U.S. Evidence Against ISIS ‘Beatles,’ Clearing Way for Trial
item.description: The men were half of a cell of Britons who held Westerners hostage in Syria, some of whom were beheaded for propaganda videos.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Supreme Court of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Alexanda Kotey, left, and El Shafee Elsheikh were members of ISIS called the “Beatles” by Westerners they held hostage.

item.title: U.K. Conservation Society Details Links to Colonialism and Slavery
item.description: The National Trust said a third of the properties it manages had direct links to colonialism or slavery. Some have a “hugely uncomfortable” history, it said.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Gareth Fuller/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The family home of Winston Churchill in Chartwell, England, is among the properties cited by Britain’s National Trust as being tied to colonialism and slavery.

item.title: A Somber Boris Johnson Offers Britain a New Plan to Halt the Virus
item.description: Fighting a second wave of infections that scientists warn could grow exponentially, the prime minister is imposing new restrictions and penalties for up to six months.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a tightening of measures for fighting the coronavirus pandemic in Britain, on Tuesday, including doubling the fine for those who do not wear face masks.

item.title: C.I.A. Reasserts Putin Is Likely Directing Election Influence Efforts to Aid Trump
item.description: The assessment, which the agency has moderate confidence in, buttresses earlier findings that the Russian president supports President Trump’s re-election.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Russia has become an authoritarian country under President Vladimir V. Putin, and little in its foreign policy occurs without his knowledge or blessing, national security officials have repeatedly said.

item.title: In Biden, China Sees an ‘Old Friend’ and Possible Foe
item.description: Some in China believe Biden, if elected, might do damage to the nation’s ambitions, taking a harder line on human rights and rallying allies to stand up to Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr., then the vice president, with Xi Jinping, now China’s leader, and their translators outside the Chinese city of Chengdu in 2011.

item.title: U.N. General Assembly: Live Updates
item.description: Deepening tensions are on display, with President Trump blaming ‘the China virus’ for global catastrophe, and Xi Jinping claiming the mantle of environmental champion.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A message pre-recorded by President Trump was played during the General Assembly on Tuesday.

item.title: Vatican Reiterates Its Opposition to Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide
item.description: As lawmakers debate right-to-life issues around the world, the Vatican says euthanasia and assisted suicide are “intrinsically evil” acts.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A new Vatican document builds on what Pope Francis has called a “throwaway culture” seeking easy solutions to alleviate suffering.

item.title: Killing of 2 Marines in 2011 Almost Derailed Afghan Peace Talks
item.description: Even as they pushed for the release of other Afghan prisoners as part of a deal with the Taliban, U.S. officials privately dug in over freeing a man who had killed Americans.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Najim Rahim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Representatives of the Afghan government and the Taliban meet in Doha, Qatar, to iron out a peace deal. The release of a Talib fighter who killed Americans was a sticking point in the negotiations.

item.title: U.K. Opposition Leader Says Boris Johnson Is ‘Just Not Up to the Job’
item.description: Keir Starmer made his first major address after taking the helm of a Labour Party that suffered a devastating election loss in December.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Keir Starmer delivering his keynote speech in Doncaster, England, on Tuesday. He was chosen as the new Labour leader, taking over from Jeremy Corbyn, in April.

item.title: Chinese City of Lanzhou Orders Taxi Drivers to Remove Tattoos
item.description: Officials in Lanzhou said tattooed drivers could “cause distress” to passengers. The order has revived a debate over stigmatized body art.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tattoo studio in Shenzhen, China, in 2018. Many younger Chinese have embraced tattooing, but others associate it with criminality.

item.title: The Fall Surge Is Here
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Tom Stromme/The Bismarck Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing site in Bismark, N.D. earlier this month.

item.title: Hundreds of Whales Stranded Off Tasmania
item.description: More than 450 pilot whales became stranded on the west coast of the island state in Australia. Rescuers estimate that over half of them have already died.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:credit: Brodie Weeding/The Advocate, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescuers worked on Tuesday to save more than 200 pilot whales stranded on the west coast of Tasmania, Australia.
